<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D170255D20F_HTM_TOC170255_8">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;5.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Operating and Financial Review and Prospects
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following discussion of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with the financial statements and the notes to those statements included elsewhere in this
	Annual Report. This discussion includes forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. As a result of many factors, such as those set forth under &#147;Item 3. Key Information&#151;Risk Factors&#148; and elsewhere in this Annual
	Report, our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are a provider of international seaborne transportation services to LPG producers and users, as well as crude oil and product carriers
	to oil producers, refineries and commodities traders. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 we operated a fleet of 51 LPG carriers, including 49 vessels we own and two vessels we charter-in, that carry various petroleum gas products in liquefied form,
	including propane, butane, butadiene, isopropane, propylene and VCM (&#147;Vinyl Chloride Monomer&#148;), three medium range product carriers that carry refined petroleum products such as gasoline, diesel, fuel oil and jet fuel, as well as edible
	oils and chemicals, and one Aframax tanker which is used for carrying crude oil. We took delivery of one newbuilding eco LPG carrier in February 2016, and sold one 1992-built, 3,500 cbm LPG carrier in January 2016. In addition, we are scheduled to
	take delivery of a further newbuilding eco LPG carrier in the third quarter of 2016, with an additional four newbuilding eco LPG carriers of 22,000 cbm each, scheduled for delivery in 2017. Once the delivery of these newbuildings is completed, our
	fleet will be composed of 54 LPG carriers, excluding the two vessels that are chartered in, with a total capacity of 334,427 cbm, three medium range product carriers with a total capacity of 140,000 dwt and one 115,804 dwt crude oil tanker, assuming
	no further acquisitions or dispositions. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015, we owned an average of 39.4, 44.1 and 48.8 vessels, respectively, generating revenues of $121.5 million, $132.0 million and $141.3 million,
	respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We, through Stealth Maritime, manage the employment of our fleet. We intend to continue to deploy our fleet
	under period charters including time and bareboat charters, which can last up to several years, and spot market or voyage charters, which generally last from one to six months, subject to market conditions. Period charters and short term time
	charters are for a fixed period of time.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Charters and revenues.
</I>
	Under a time charter, the charterer pays a fixed rate per day over the term of the charter; a time charter, including a
	short term time charter, may provide for rate adjustments and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	43
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	profit sharing. Under a bareboat charter, the charterer pays us a fixed rate for its use of our ship for the term of the charter. Under a voyage charter, we agree to transport a specified cargo
	from a loading port to a discharging port for a fixed amount.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Charters and expenses
</I>
	. Under a time charter, we are responsible for the vessel&#146;s operating costs (crew, provisions, stores, lubricants,
	insurance, maintenance and repairs) incurred during the term of the charter, while the charterer pays voyage expenses (port, canal and fuel costs) that are unique to each particular voyage. Under a bareboat charter, the charterer is responsible for
	all vessel operating expenses and voyage expenses incurred during the term of the charter. Under a voyage or spot charter, we are responsible for both the vessel operating expenses and the voyage expenses incurred in performing the charter
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of April&nbsp;1, 2016, 11 of our LPG carriers, two of our medium range product carriers and our Aframax
	crude oil tanker were deployed on bareboat charters, under which the charterer is responsible for the costs associated with the operations of the vessels. Of the remaining vessels in our fleet, as of April&nbsp;1, 2016, 13 were employed in the spot
	market, with the remaining vessels deployed on time charters. As of April&nbsp;1, 2016, 62% of our anticipated fleet days for the existing fleet were covered by period charter contracts for the remainder of 2016 and 32% for 2017 (in each case
	excluding the newbuilding LPG carriers which we have agreed to acquire, but have not yet been delivered). The corresponding forward coverage as of April&nbsp;1, 2015 was 63% for the remainder of 2015 and 34% for 2016. We are, however, exposed to
	prevailing charter rate fluctuations for the remaining anticipated fleet days not covered by period charter contracts, as well as performance by our counterparties for the chartered days.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	A. Operating Results
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We believe that the important measures for analyzing trends in the results of our operations consist of the following:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Calendar days
</I>
	. We define calendar days as the total number of days in a period during which each vessel in our fleet was in our possession
	including off-hire days associated with major repairs, drydockings or special or intermediate surveys. Calendar days are an indicator of the size of our fleet over a period and affect both the amount of revenue and the amount of expense that we
	record during that period
<I>
	.
</I>
	In January 2016, we sold the 1992-built, 3,500 cbm LPG carrier
<I>
	Gas Arctic
</I>
	. We may also elect to sell additional older vessels in our fleet from time to time. Six of our LPG carriers are subject to
	arrangements pursuant to which the charterer has options to purchase the vessels at declining stipulated prices at any time during the current charter for the respective vessels, in addition three of our vessels are subject to arrangements pursuant
	to which the charterer has options to purchase the vessels at the end of their current charters in 2021 and 2022. If any of these purchase options were to be exercised, the expected size of our LPG carrier fleet would be reduced, and as a result our
	anticipated level of calendar days and revenues would be reduced.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Voyage days
</I>
	. We define voyage days as the total number of days in a period during which each vessel in our fleet was in our possession net of
	off-hire days associated with major repairs, drydockings or special or intermediate surveys. The shipping industry uses voyage days (also referred to as available days) to measure the number of days in a period during which vessels are available to
	generate revenues.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Fleet utilization; Fleet operational utilization
</I>
	. We calculate fleet utilization by dividing the number of our voyage days during a period by
	the number of our calendar days during that period, and we calculate fleet operational utilization by dividing the number of our voyage days (excluding commercially idle days) during a period by the number of our calendar days during that period.
	The shipping industry uses fleet utilization to measure a company&#146;s efficiency in minimizing the amount of
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	44
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	days that its vessels are off-hire for reasons such as scheduled repairs, vessel upgrades or drydockings and other surveys, and uses fleet operational utilization to also measure a company&#146;s
	efficiency in finding suitable employment for its vessels.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Cyclicality.
</I>
	The international gas carrier market, including the transport of LPG, is cyclical with attendant volatility in profitability,
	charter rates and vessel values, resulting from changes in the supply of, and demand for, LPG carrier capacity. From the last quarter of 2011 until the third quarter of 2014, LPG carrier market conditions generally improved from low levels with
	higher LPG carrier charter rates and utilization levels, however, the impact of the dramatic decline in oil prices on demand for LPG has adversely affected LPG carrier charter rates and utilization levels since the fourth quarter of 2014,
	particularly in the smaller vessel classes. As of April&nbsp;1, 2016, we had 13 vessels trading in the spot market. We expect to take delivery of five LPG carrier newbuildings from the third quarter of 2016 to the third quarter of 2017. Four of
	these newbuilding vessels, each scheduled to be delivered in 2017, do not yet have employment arranged. Charter rates remain subject to further downside risks, including in the event of increased weakness in the global economy and lower demand for
	the seaborne transport of LPG, which may result from lower oil prices and reduced supply from lower oil and natural gas production.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:8%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	With regard to the vessels in the spot market, we are exposed to changes in spot rates for LPG carriers and such changes affect our earnings and the value of our LPG carriers at any given time. When LPG
	vessel prices are considered to be low, companies not usually involved in shipping may make speculative vessel orders, thereby increasing the global supply of LPG carriers, satisfying demand sooner and potentially suppressing charter rates. With
	regard to the four tankers in our fleet, one of our product carriers is on a fixed rate time charter expiring in July 2016 and two of the product carriers are deployed on fixed rate bareboat charters expiring in 2017 and 2019, while the Aframax
	tanker is deployed on a fixed rate bareboat charter that expires in 2018, which has limited our exposure to fluctuations in charter rates for these vessels. However they will be exposed to prevailing charter rates in the product tanker sector when
	their existing charters expire.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Seasonality.
</I>
	The LPG carrier market is typically stronger in the fall and winter months in anticipation of increased consumption of propane and
	butane for heating during the winter months. In addition, unpredictable weather patterns in these months tend to disrupt vessel scheduling and supplies of certain commodities. As a result, our revenues may be stronger in fiscal quarters ending
	December&nbsp;31 and March&nbsp;31 and relatively weaker during the fiscal quarters ending June&nbsp;30 and September&nbsp;30, as was the case in 2013, 2014 and 2015. We have limited exposure to seasonality with respect to our product carriers and
	Aframax tanker as these are deployed on long term or medium term fixed rate charters.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our
	ability to control our fixed and variable expenses, including those for commission expenses, crew wages and related costs, the cost of insurance, expenses for repairs and maintenance, the cost of spares and consumable stores, tonnage taxes and other
	miscellaneous expenses also affect our financial results. Factors beyond our control, such as developments relating to market premiums for insurance and the value of the U.S. dollar compared to currencies in which certain of our expenses, primarily
	crew wages, are denominated can also cause our vessel operating expenses to increase. In addition, our net income is affected by our financing arrangements, including our interest rate swap arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Basis of Presentation and General Information
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Revenues
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our voyage revenues are driven primarily by the number of
	vessels in our fleet, the number of voyage days during which our vessels generate revenues and the amount of daily charter hire that our vessels earn under charters which, in turn, are affected by a number of factors, including our decisions
	relating to vessel acquisitions and disposals, the amount of time that we spend positioning our vessels, the amount of time that our vessels spend in dry dock undergoing repairs, maintenance and upgrade work, the age, condition and specifications of
	our vessels and the levels of supply and demand in the LPG carrier, product carrier and crude oil tanker charter markets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	45
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We employ our vessels under time, bareboat and spot charters. Bareboat charters provide for
	the charterer to bear the cost of operating the vessel and as such typically market rates for bareboat charters are lower than those for time charters. Vessels operating on period charters, principally time and bareboat charters, provide more
	predictable cash flows, but can yield lower profit margins than vessels operating in the spot charter market during periods characterized by favorable market conditions. As a result, during the time our vessels are committed on period charters we
	will be unable, during periods of improving charter markets, to take advantage of improving charter rates as we could if our vessels were employed only on spot charters. Vessels operating in the spot charter market generate revenues that are less
	predictable but may enable us to capture increased profit margins during periods of improving charter rates, although we are then exposed to the risk of declining LPG carrier, product carrier or crude oil tanker charter rates, which may have a
	materially adverse impact on our financial performance. If we commit vessels on period charters, future spot market rates may be higher or lower than those rates at which we have time chartered our vessels.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Voyage Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Voyage expenses include port and canal charges, bunkers (fuel oil) expenses and commissions. These charges and expenses increase in
	periods during which vessels are employed on the spot market, because under these charters, these expenses are for the account of the vessel owner. Under period charters, these charges and expenses, including bunkers (fuel oil) but excluding
	commissions which are always paid by the vessel owner, are paid by the charterer. Bunkers (fuel oil), the price of which has declined since the third quarter of 2014 as a result of the decline in oil prices, accounted for 48.7% of total voyage
	expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 53.6% of total voyage expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 58.4% of total voyage expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Commissions on hire are paid to our manager
	Stealth Maritime and/or third party brokers. Stealth Maritime receives a fixed brokerage commission of 1.25% on freight, hire and demurrage for each vessel based on our management agreement since 2005. In 2015, port and canal charges and bunker
	expenses represented a relatively small portion of our vessels&#146; overall expenses, 9.8%, because the majority of our vessels were employed under period charters, including time and bareboat charters, that require the charterer to bear such
	expenses. As of April&nbsp;1, 2016, we had 13 vessels in the spot market for which we pay voyage expenses; the corresponding number as of April&nbsp;1, 2015 was ten and as of April&nbsp;1, 2014 was five.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Vessel Operating Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Vessel operating expenses include crew wages and related costs, the cost of insurance, expenses for repairs and maintenance, the cost of spares and consumable stores, tonnage taxes and other miscellaneous
	expenses. Our ability to control these fixed and variable expenses, also affects our financial results. In addition, the type of charter under which our vessels are employed (time, bareboat or spot charter) also affects our operating expenses
	because we do not pay the operating expenses of vessels that we deploy on bareboat charters. Factors beyond our control, some of which may affect the shipping industry in general, including, for instance, developments relating to market prices for
	insurance and regulations related to safety and environmental matters may also cause these expenses to increase.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Management Fees
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	During 2015, we paid Stealth Maritime, our fleet manager, a fixed rate management fee of $440 per day for each vessel
	in our fleet under spot or time charter and a fixed rate fee of $125 per day for each of the vessels operating on bareboat charter. These rates have been in effect since January&nbsp;1, 2007. Stealth Maritime also receives a fee equal to 1.0%
	calculated on the price stated in the relevant memorandum of agreement for any vessel bought or sold by them on our behalf. From these management fees paid to Stealth Maritime, Stealth Maritime pays one technical manager that is responsible for the
	technical management of some of our vessels that are not technically managed by Stealth Maritime on a day-to-day basis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	46
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We incur general and administrative expenses that consist primarily of legal fees, audit fees, office rental fees, officers and board
	remuneration or reimbursement, directors and officers insurance, listing fees and other general and administrative expenses. Our general and administrative expenses also include our direct compensation expenses and the value of non-cash executive
	services provided through, and other expenses arising from, our management agreement with Stealth Maritime, our directors&#146; compensation and the value of the lease expense for the space we rent from Stealth Maritime. For our compensation
	expenses, pursuant to our management agreement, we reimburse Stealth Maritime for its payment of the compensation of our Chief Executive Officer, Deputy Chairman and Executive Director, Chief Technical Officer, and Internal Auditor. During the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, such compensation was in the aggregate amount of $1.1 million. We had $0.5 million of unrecognized stock-based compensation expense as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, relating to equity awards issued to our executive
	officers and non-executive members of our Board of Directors in 2014. Of these equity awards, 50% vested in November 2015, 25% are scheduled to vest in November 2016 and 25% are scheduled to vest in November 2017. Such expenses will be recognized as
	general and administrative expenses over the vesting period until November 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Inflation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Inflation has only a moderate effect on our expenses given current economic conditions. In the event that significant global inflationary
	pressures appear, these pressures would increase our operating, voyage, administrative and financing expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Depreciation and Dry
	docking
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We depreciate our vessels on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives, determined to be 30
	years from the date of their initial delivery from the shipyard in the case of our LPG carriers and 25 years in the case of our product carriers and crude oil tanker. Depreciation is based on cost less the estimated scrap value of the vessels. We
	expense costs associated with dry dockings and special and intermediate surveys as incurred which may affect the volatility of our results. During 2015, we dry docked four vessels at a total cost of $1.8 million. We expect that during 2016 our dry
	docking costs will be higher, as seven vessels are scheduled to be dry docked in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Impairment Loss
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based on the accounting standards followed by the Company, impairment losses are recognized on long-lived assets used in operations when
	indicators of impairment are present and the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets are less than their carrying amounts and the asset&#146;s carrying value exceeds its fair value. If indicators of impairment are present,
	the Company performs an analysis of the anticipated undiscounted future net cash flows of the related long-lived assets. If the carrying value of the related asset exceeds the undiscounted cash flows, the carrying value is reduced to its fair value
	and the difference is recorded as an impairment loss in the consolidated statements of income. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we recognized an impairment loss of $8.2 million with respect to three of our older vessels. In December 2014,
	the Company recognized an impairment loss of $6.2 million on two vessels scrapped within 2015. No impairment loss was identified or recorded for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Gain / Loss on Sale of Vessels
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The carrying value of our vessels
	includes the original cost of the vessels plus capitalized expenses since acquisition relating to improvements and upgrading of the vessel, less accumulated depreciation and less any impairment. Depreciation is calculated using the straight line
	method, from the date the vessel was originally built, over an estimated useful life of 25 years for the tankers in our fleet and 30 years for the LPG carriers in our fleet. LPG carriers tend to trade for longer periods due to the less corrosive
	nature of the cargoes they carry. Residual values used in depreciation calculations are based on $350 per light weight ton.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	47
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On January&nbsp;21, 2016, we sold the
<I>
	Gas Arctic
</I>
	for which we recognized a gain of
	$0.3 million. On April&nbsp;1, 2015, we sold the
<I>
	Gas Kaizen,
</I>
	while on April&nbsp;16, 2015 we sold the
<I>
	Gas Crystal,
</I>
	both for demolition; we recognized a gain of $0.02 million and $0.01 million respectively on the sale of these two
	vessels. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, we sold two vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Cathar
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Gas Premiership
</I>
	that were leased back by our Company on a bareboat hire basis for a period of four years. The aforementioned transaction
	is classified as a sale and lease back transaction and in accordance with US&nbsp;GAAP ASC, 840-40, the net gain on sale of vessels of $0.8 million must be amortized throughout the lease period of the vessels. During the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2013, no vessels were sold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Loss on Derivatives
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Five of our seven interest rate swaps, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, are accounted for as cash flow hedges and the changes in their fair values are recorded in &#147;Accumulated other comprehensive
	income/loss&#148;, while the other two interest rate swaps expired in March 2016. All changes in the fair value of our cash flow interest rate swaps and foreign currency exchange agreements that are not accounted for as cash flow hedges, are
	recorded in earnings under &#147;Loss on Derivatives.&#148; To the extent we have interest rate swaps and foreign currency exchange agreements in this category, this increases the potential volatility in our reported earnings, in comparison to the
	case where such arrangements did qualify for hedge accounting, due to the recognition of non-cash fair value movements of our cash flow interest rate swaps and foreign currency exchange arrangements directly in our statement of income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Expense and Finance Costs
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We have entered into credit facilities to fund a portion of the purchase price of the vessels in our fleet, which are described in the &#147;Credit Facilities&#148; section below. We incur interest
	expense on outstanding indebtedness under these credit facilities, which we include in interest expense. We also incurred financing costs in connection with establishing those facilities, which are deferred and amortized over the period of the
	facility, which we also include in interest expense. We will incur additional interest expenses under any new credit facilities we enter into to finance or refinance the purchase price of additional vessels as described in the &#147;Liquidity and
	Capital Resources&#148; section below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Results of Operations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The average number of vessels in our fleet was 48.8 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 44.1 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	REVENUES&#151;Voyage revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $141.3 million compared to $132.0 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $9.3 million. Total calendar days for our fleet were 18,541 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 16,136 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014; due to the increase in the average number of
	vessels in our fleet. Of the total calendar days in 2015, 5,543 or 29.9% were bareboat charter days and 8,973 or 48.4% were time charter days. This compares to 5,201 or 32.2% bareboat charter days and 8,692 or 53.9% time charter days in 2014. Our
	fleet operational utilization was 92.5% and 93.3% for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, respectively. Although rates have decreased, revenues increased in 2015 due primarily to the higher number of voyage days for
	our fleet.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	VOYAGE EXPENSES&#151;Voyage expenses were $17.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to
	$14.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $3.5 million, or 24.8%. This was primarily due the higher number of vessels operating under spot charters. Voyage expenses consisted largely of bunker charges in the amount of
	$8.6 million for 2015 compared to bunker charges in the amount of $7.6 million for 2014, an increase of $1.0 million, due to the increase in the number of spot charter days. Under spot
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	48
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage51"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	charters we are responsible for paying the vessels&#146; bunkers consumption, as well as most expenses. Voyage expenses also included port expenses of $4.0 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $2.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $1.7 million and commissions to third parties which were $2.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $2.1 million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $0.3 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	VESSEL OPERATING EXPENSES&#151;Vessel operating expenses
	were $50.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $45.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $5.3 million, or 11.7%. The main reason for this increase was the higher number of vessels in the fleet,
	as ten new vessels were added to our fleet. Other components of vessel operating expenses were spares and consumable stores, which increased from $7.1 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 to $8.0 million in the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 while repairs and maintenance costs were $5.2 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $5.1 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	DRY DOCKING COSTS&#151;Dry docking costs were $1.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $0.5 million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $1.3 million, or 260%. Dry docking costs increased due to a higher number of vessels having to undergo dry docking inspections in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the number of
	vessels that underwent dry docking inspections in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, four vessels were dry docked compared to one vessel for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	MANAGEMENT FEES&#151;Management fees were $6.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $5.5 million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $1.0 million or 18.2%. The increase was due to the higher average number of vessels in the fleet; 48.8 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 44.1 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
	The daily management fees per vessel did not change during these periods. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 69.6% of our total calendar days related to vessels under time or spot charter while for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	67.8% related to vessels under time or spot charter. Accordingly, both the total number of calendar days due to the increase in the average size of our fleet and the number of time and spot charter days, for each of which the higher rate of $440 per
	vessel per day management fee was paid, compared to bareboat charter days, for which the lower $125 per vessel per day management fee was paid, increased in 2015 from 2014. As a result of the above, management fees increased.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES&#151;General and administrative expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $3.7 million
	compared to $3.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of $0.5 million or 15.6%. Included in the general and administrative expenses for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014 are $1.1 million and
	$1.3 million, respectively, paid to our manager for the services of the Company&#146;s executive officers pursuant to our management agreement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	DEPRECIATION&#151;Depreciation expenses for the 48.8 average number of vessels in our fleet for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $35.9 million compared to $33.8 million for the 44.1 average
	number of vessels in our fleet for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 an increase of $2.1 million, or 6.2%. The increase is due to the higher average number of vessels in our fleet in the 2015 period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	IMPAIRMENT LOSS&#151;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company recognized an impairment loss of $8.2 million, while for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 the Company recognized an impairment loss of $6.2 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	NET GAIN ON SALE OF
	VESSELS&#151;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 we sold two of our oldest vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Kaizen
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Gas Crystal
</I>
	for demolition. The net gain on the sale of these vessels was $33.3 thousands. During the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, we sold two vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Cathar
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Gas Premiership
</I>
	, that were leased back by our Company on a bareboat hire basis for a period of four years. The aforementioned transaction is classified as a sale and
	lease back transaction and in accordance with US&nbsp;GAAP
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	ASC, 840-40, the net gain on sale of vessels of $0.8 million, is amortized throughout the lease period of the vessels. Amortization of deferred gain on sale and leaseback of the vessels for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $0.2 million and is included in Charter hire expenses in the consolidated statements of income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	INTEREST AND FINANCE COSTS&#151;Interest and finance costs were $10.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $9.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, an increase of
	$1.1 million, or 11.8%. The increase in interest and finance cost was mainly due to an increase in loan interest expenses as a result to increase in our leverage.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	LOSS ON DERIVATIVES&#151;Included in the results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 are net losses from interest rate derivative instruments and foreign currency hedging arrangements of $0.4
	million. Interest paid on interest rate swap arrangements amounted to $1.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $1.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and net gains from change in fair value of the same
	arrangements amounted to $1.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $1.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	INTEREST INCOME&#151;Interest income was $0.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $0.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, a decrease of $0.3 million, related
	mostly to lower interest on deposits offered by financial institutions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	NET INCOME&#151;As a result of the above factors, we
	recorded a net income of $2.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to net income of $12.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The average number of vessels in our fleet was 44.1 in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 39.4 in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	REVENUES&#151;Voyage revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were $132.0 million compared to $121.5 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $10.5 million. Total calendar days for our fleet were 16,136 in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 14,399 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013; the difference was due to the increase in the
	average number of vessels in our fleet. Of the total calendar days in 2014, 5,201, or 32.2% were bareboat charter days and 8,692, or 53.9% were time charter days. This compares to 4,944, or 34.3%, bareboat charter days and 6,952, or 48.3%, time
	charter days in 2013. Our fleet operational utilization was 93.3% and 92.3% for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013 respectively. Although rates have decreased, revenues increased in 2014 due primarily to the higher
	number of calendar days for our fleet.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	VOYAGE EXPENSES&#151;Voyage expenses were $14.1 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $14.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, a decrease of $0.2 million, or 1.4%. This was primarily due the lower number of vessels operating under spot charters. Voyage expenses consisted largely of
	bunker charges in the amount of $7.6 million for 2014 compared to bunker charges in the amount of $8.3 million for 2013, a decrease of $0.7 million, due to the decrease in the number of spot charter days. Under spot charters we are responsible for
	paying the vessels&#146; bunkers consumption, as well as most expenses. Voyage expenses also included port expenses of $2.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $2.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an
	increase of $0.2 million and commissions to third parties which were $2.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $1.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $0.3 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	VESSEL OPERATING EXPENSES&#151;Vessel operating expenses were $45.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $36.5
	million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $8.9 million, or 24.4%. The main reason for this increase was the higher number of vessels in the fleet, as five new
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	50
</FONT>
</P>

</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	vessels were added and two more vessels came off bareboat charters and were operated under time charters during 2014. Other components of vessel operating expenses were spares and consumable
	stores, which increased from $5.8 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 to $7.1 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, while repairs and maintenance costs were $5.2 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to
	$4.2 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	DRY DOCKING COSTS&#151;Dry docking costs were $0.5 million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $ 3.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, a decrease of $2.7 million, or 84.4%. Dry docking costs decreased due to a lower number of vessels having to undergo dry docking inspections
	in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the number of vessels that underwent dry docking inspections in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, one vessel was dry docked compared to seven
	vessels for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	MANAGEMENT FEES&#151;Management fees were $5.5 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $4.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $0.7 million or 14.6%. The increase was due to the higher average number of vessels in the fleet; 44.1 for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2014 compared to 39.4 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The daily management fees per vessel did not change during these periods. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, 67.8% of our total calendar days related to vessels under time or
	spot charter while for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 65.7% related to vessels under time or spot charter. Accordingly, both the total number of calendar days due to the increase in the average size of our fleet and the number of time and
	spot charter days, for each of which the higher $440 per vessel per day management fee was paid, compared to bareboat charter days, for which the lower $125 per vessel per day management fee was paid, increased in 2014 from 2013. As a result of the
	above, management fees increased.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	GENERAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES&#151;General and administrative expenses for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were $3.2 million compared to $2.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $0.4 million or 14.3%. Included in the general and administrative expenses for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	and December&nbsp;31, 2013 are $1.3 million and $1.2 million, respectively, paid to our manager for the services of the Company&#146;s executive officers pursuant to our management agreement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	DEPRECIATION&#151;Depreciation expenses for the 44.1 average number of vessels in our fleet for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	were $33.8 million compared to $30.8 million for the 39.4 average number of vessels in our fleet for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $3.0 million, or 9.7%. The increase is due to the higher average number of vessels in our
	fleet in the 2014 period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	IMPAIRMENT LOSS&#151;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the Company recognized an
	impairment loss of $6.2 million on vessels planned to be scrapped within 2015. No impairment loss was recognized in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	NET
	GAIN ON SALE OF VESSELS&#151;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, we sold two vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Cathar
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Gas Premiership
</I>
	, that were leased back by our Company on a bareboat hire basis for a period of four years. The
	aforementioned transaction is classified as a sale and lease back transaction and in accordance with US&nbsp;GAAP ASC, 840-40, the net gain on sale of vessels of $0.8 million, will be amortized throughout the lease period of the vessels.
	Amortization of deferred gain on sale and leaseback of the vessels for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $0.005 million and is included in Charter hire expenses in the consolidated statement of income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	INTEREST AND FINANCE COSTS&#151;Interest and finance costs were $ 9.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to
	$8.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $1.1 million, or 13.4%. The increase in interest and finance cost was mainly due to an increase in commitment costs relating to the financing arranged for vessels that are
	currently under construction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

	LOSS ON DERIVATIVES&#151;Included in the results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014
	are net losses from interest rate derivative instruments and foreign currency hedging arrangements of $ 1.3 million. Interest paid on interest rate swap arrangements amounted to $1.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to
	$2.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 and net gains from change in fair value of the same arrangements amounted to $1.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $2.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2013.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	INTEREST INCOME&#151;Interest income was $0.5 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, compared to $0.4
	million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, an increase of $0.1 million, related to higher average cash balances on deposit throughout the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	NET INCOME&#151;As a result of the above factors, we recorded a net income of $12.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	compared to net income of $21.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	A. Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had cash and cash equivalents of $100.1 million and $13.5 million in restricted cash classified as
	current assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our principal sources of funds for our liquidity needs are cash flows from operations and long-term bank
	borrowings. Additional sources of funds include proceeds from vessel sales and equity offerings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We had net proceeds of $2.0
	million from vessel sales in 2015 and $27.9 million in 2014. We sold the
<I>
	Gas Arctic
</I>
	on January&nbsp;21, 2016 from which we received net proceeds of $1.1 million. We raised capital through a follow-on public common stock offering in the second
	quarter of 2013 with net proceeds of $109.1 million and in 2014 through three registered common stock offerings with net proceeds of approximately $112.3 million. Our principal use of funds has been to acquire our vessels, maintain the quality of
	our vessels, service our debt and fund working capital requirements, as well to repurchase shares of our common stock as described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our liquidity needs, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 through the end of 2016, primarily relate to scheduled debt repayments, funding expenses for operating our vessels, general and administrative expenses
	and capital expenditures related to the acquisition of two LPG carriers. Generally, our primary sources of funds, in the short term, have been cash from operating activities, and, in the long term, bank borrowings and equity financings. As of
	April&nbsp;1, 2016 we had already taken the delivery of one LPG carrier. We expect to fund the remaining purchase price of $18.6 million for one newbuilding vessel scheduled to be delivered in the third quarter of 2016, with available cash and
	borrowings under a new credit facility for which we have a commitment letter. Beyond 2016, our liquidity needs will additionally include capital expenditures for the remaining balance of the purchase price of four additional LPG carrier newbuildings
	which amounts to approximately $145.8 million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had paid a total of $44.0 million in deposits
	for six LPG carrier newbuildings which had a $208.2 million remaining purchase price. The aforementioned amount is payable in the amount of $62.4 million in 2016 and $145.8 million in 2017. From January&nbsp;1, 2016 to April&nbsp;1, 2016, we took
	delivery of one newbuilding eco LPG carrier and paid $4.0 million from cash on hand and $15.6 million from new bank borrowings. We expect to fund the remaining amount of the purchase price for the remaining newbuildings through existing and
	internally generated funds and new credit facilities. As of April&nbsp;1, 2016 we had obtained commitment letters or entered into loan agreements for three of our newbuildings while for the remaining two we had a signed loan term sheet in respect of
	which the commitment of the funds is in the process of bank credit committee approval. The total amount under the aforementioned committed loans is up to $92.5 million and under the loans for which we have a term sheet subject to credit committee
	approval expected to be up to $76.0 million, in each case depending on the vessels&#146; employment and market value at the time of their respective deliveries in 2016 and 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	52
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, our aggregate debt outstanding net of capitalized arrangement
	fees was $422.2 million, of which $74.9 million was payable within 12 months. This amount includes a balloon payment of approximately $24.6 million which may be refinanced within 2016. We believe our working capital is sufficient for our present
	short-term liquidity requirements. If there is a major and sustained downturn in market conditions applicable to our specific shipping industry segment our ability to draw down the full amount of certain of our committed credit facilities may be
	restricted. These facilities contain restrictions on the amount of cash that can be advanced to us based on the market value, or in some cases employment, of the vessel in respect of which the advance is being made. We believe our internally
	generated cash flows and the borrowings under already arranged credit facilities will be sufficient to fund our operations, including working capital requirements, for at least 12 months taking into account our existing capital commitments and debt
	service requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For a description of our credit facilities please refer to the discussion under the heading
	&#147;&#151;Credit Facilities&#148; below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On November&nbsp;26, 2014, we publicly announced that our Board of Directors had
	authorized the repurchase of up to $10,000,000 of shares of our common stock and on February&nbsp;26, 2015 we publicly announced that our Board of Directors had approved an additional $20,000,000 of common stock repurchases. There is no fixed time
	period for this repurchase program. As of April&nbsp;1, 2016, 3,859,297 shares of common stock had been repurchased for an aggregate of $20.2 million. Our dividend policy will also affect our liquidity position. See &#147;Item 8. Financial
	Information&#151;Dividend Policy.&#148;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cash Flows
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash provided by operating activities&#151;was $48.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, $55.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, and $49.1 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2013. This represents the net amount of cash, after expenses, generated by chartering our vessels. The decrease in net cash provided by operating activities in 2015 was mainly due to the lower net income as a result of increased
	voyage and operating costs due to our fleet expansion and the decline in freight rates that took place in 2015. The increase in net cash provided by operating activities in 2014 was mainly due to the increase in revenues (net of voyage expenses)
	generated by operations due to the higher number of vessels in our fleet and the decrease in the drydocking costs which amounted to $3.2 million in 2013, and $0.5 million in 2014 and corresponding to one vessel being drydocked in 2014, compared to
	seven vessels drydocked in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash used in investing activities&#151;was $165.0 million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, $91.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and $119.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. During 2015, we acquired ten LPG vessels, the
<I>
	Eco Lucidity
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Enigma
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco
	Galaxy
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Universe
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Royalty
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Loyalty
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Dream
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Green
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Nemesis
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Eco Czar
</I>
	, for which we paid a total of $149.9 million. In addition to payments
	related to vessel deliveries for 2015, during the aforementioned year we paid an amount of $5.2 million as advances for the five vessels expected to be delivered in the years 2016 and 2017. With regards to the sale of vessels, during 2015 we sold
	two of our oldest vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Kaizen
</I>
	and the
<I>
	Gas Crystal
</I>
	, for demolition, with net sale proceeds of $2.0 million. During 2014, we acquired five LPG vessels, the
<I>
	Eco Stream
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Chios
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Invictus
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Eco Elysium
</I>
	, and the
<I>
	Eco Corsair
</I>
	, for which we paid $81.6 million. During 2014 we also agreed to acquire sixteen newbuildings for which we paid advances of $48.4 million. During 2014 we sold two vessels, the
<I>
	Gas Cathar
</I>
	and
<I>
	Gas Premiership
</I>
	, with net proceeds of $27.9 million and we had net proceeds related to the cancellation of vessels acquisition amounting to $10.0 million. During 2013, outflows of $73.2 million reflect payments to the shipyard for the
	delivery of the
<I>
	Gas Enchanted
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Gas Alice
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Gas Inspiration
</I>
	, the
<I>
	Gas Ethereal
</I>
	, and the
<I>
	Sakura Symphony
</I>
	, while $51.2 million was paid as a deposit for the acquisition of 11 newbuilding vessels under
	construction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash provided by financing activities&#151;was $87.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015
	consisting mainly of $155.1 million in proceeds from long-term debt while $55.9 million in loan repayments of which $42.4 million were regular loan installments and $13.5 million was a voluntary repayment of an existing
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	53
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage56"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D170255D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	credit facility. In addition, in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, $13.4 million was spent in relation to the Company&#146;s stock repurchase program. Net cash provided by financing
	activities was $79.0 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 consisting mainly of $112.3 million net proceeds from common stock issuances, $47.9 million in loan proceeds for the acquisition of five vessels and $75.3 million in loan
	repayments of which $42.5 million were regular loan installments, $13.8 million were repayments related to the sale of vessels in 2014 and $19.0 million was a voluntary repayment of an existing credit facility. Net cash provided by financing
	activities was $114.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 consisting principally of $109.1 million net proceeds from common stock issuance, $45.2 million in bank loan proceeds for the acquisition of five vessels and $37.7 million in
	loan repayments under existing facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As and when we identify assets that we believe will provide attractive returns, we
	generally enter into specific term loan facilities and borrow amounts under these facilities as the vessels are delivered to us. This is the primary driver of the timing and amount of cash provided to us by our financing activities, however, from
	time to time to bolster our cash position and take advantage of financing opportunities, including to refinance the acquisition cost of vessels acquired earlier, we have entered into and may in the future borrow under credit facilities secured by
	previously unencumbered vessels in our then-existing fleet.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Credit Facilities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We, and certain of our subsidiaries, have entered into a number of credit facilities in connection with financing the acquisition of
	certain vessels in our fleet. The following summarizes certain terms of our credit facilities under which we had aggregate outstanding indebtedness of $422.2 million, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 which is reflected in our balance sheet as
	&#147;Long-term debt&#148; and &#147;Current portion of long-term debt.&#148; For a description of our credit facilities also see Note 11 to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
